author: investri
body:
I think this is a great take. And don’t just limit your search to major processor suppliers.

Would also look into companies that supply all of the peripheral chips for auto and consumer electronics (think TXN, ADI). Your average BOM includes 1 main processor, and many, many peripheral chips.. Peripheral chips are typically cheaper, less competitive, built on more stable processing nodes, and have high margins.

One other company of interest related to semiconductors is TER. Wide moat tester supplier for just about every one of these chip makers. The need for comprehensive test solutions is growing (arguably) faster than the semiconductor market itself, especially as INTC and AAPL are reaching their 5-7nm process nodes. 

- An engineer in the semiconductor industry

author: ReversalTheory
body: Cathie bought TER yesterday and it's down 3.75% today lol ARK hype is dead

The rule is if you need the money within 5 years, don't invest it in the stock market.

DCA over 1 year adds on average a 0.38% TER to your portfolio.

https://rationalreminder.ca/podcast/101

Ben Felix explained it in one of his podcasts. Timestamp at 31:49. The 0.38% number is at timestamp 38:32.

By not having all of your money tied to the stock market at T+0, you aren't efficiently capturing the rise of the market as a whole. This results in underperformance of your portfolio compared to the market. 

He looked at 10-year rolling periods (Jan 1970 - Jan 1980, Feb 1970 - Feb 1980, etc), individually in Australia, Canada, Germany, Japan, UK, and the US, of 100% equity portfolios. DCA was done with $1 million over 12 months. 

On average, the annual growth of the DCA portfolio trailed the lump sum portfolio by 0.38%.

*He also looked at bear markets (20% drop) and bull markets (95% of highest P/E ratios), and lump sum still beat DCA >50% of the time.

author: xModulus
body:
> pay a professional to do it for you 

No thanks. Actively managed funds are even worse than index funds. Why are you peddling such shit advice. The best thing for a layperson to do is buy the entire international market (via a very low expense ratio ETF) every month for the next 30 years, and they'll be guaranteed to come out ahead of most mutual funds. Why pay some retard 1-2% of my portfolio annually when it's not even guaranteed they'll beat the benchmarks. Those fees add up A LOT when you take into account compounding. My 0.07% TER S&P500 ETF would definitely beat 90% of mutual funds out there in the 30 year time frame, and that is a fact backed by math.

Take a moment to assume everyone follows your advice and picks a "diversified" portfolio of stocks, just as there will be winners, there will also definitely be people (including well paid hedge fund managers) who lose out and perform worse than the market. And thus your advice breaks down easily and should not be taken by the average person.

author: notdoingdrugs
body:
My opinion but with disclosure: I own CGC and TPCO

Martha’s branding is for the states - where CGC can’t even fully operate yet, I’d hesitate to call this a bust anytime in the next year or two. CBD may be legal but the market’s oversaturated already and CGC as an (still primarily only due to regs) LP doesn’t get to market itself everywhere in the U.S. it needs to to gain CBD market share. Further, I guarantee Martha will be creating THC edibles, too, again, once allowed in the U.S. It’s way too early.

Snoop partnership essentially got fucked because of the HC no advertising and celeb promotions rules no? Sure some people know what the strain LBS stands for but they didn’t even get to utilize this brand for the masses.

I never owned Invictus but watched the GENE bullshit go down. If TPCO had changed their ticker to JAYZ I woulda immediately sold lmao. No, to me, Jay’s involvement is beyond name rec celebrity pumpity pump and actually in creating the first successful California cannabis consolidator. CA’s market is begging for this (and I love their omnichannel client intel) per just the last few years in changing license requirements and trying to rid the state of the black and grey market that’s persisted post legalization. Jay’s legit on wanting to give back to minority owned business start ups - anyone that’s followed that guy’s life and career should agree there. TPCO started a foundation and donating what is it 2% of net profits annually - is gonna be huge press attention.

I also love the cap-light business model. Fuck all of the hundreds of millions spent by the top MSOs on multiple cultivation sites in multiple states when interstate commerce is going to bleed these dry eventually. It’s why I think CGC and ACRG + TER win in the long run by contracting out flower growing and don’t wanna be farmers. I could def be wrong but I like Michael Auerbach and bought more TPCO warrants this morning.

author: ganbaro
body:
I mean, the free trades are usually the ETFs with above-average TER for the respective Index.

When you do the trade, you save X compared to buying the ETF with lower TER and paying trade fees. However, doing so you pay a TER which is higher than for the ETF with trade fees. Let's the difference between the TERs be called Y. How long do you need to hold the ETF until the sum of Y for any single investment exceeds the savings X? If you plan to hold longer than that, it might be better to just accept the fees.

Trade Republic seems to plan to provide some data starting later in 2021 which should help Austrian residents with filling out the tax forms. They might start a Austrian-domiciled daughter and become "steuereinfach" in the long term. Can't hurt to keep an eye out for them, it's not like we have that many other reasonable options here except FlatEx and dadat.

author: marketplaced
body:
Yeah I agree with you, traditional farming is going to decline long term, everything is changing, farming is no different. I think AppHarvest is gonna make farming a lot more efficient, I believe they are using people for some stuff now and automated systems for the other parts they can automate easily. 

I think [Raven Industries](https://ravenind.com/) (RAVN) also does some interesting farming equipment in addition to a bunch of other stuff, seems like it's basically a company of baller engineers getting together to work on stuff they think is cool in South Dakota, very interesting to me, got my parents in it but don't have a position personally since no liquid cash for it at the time and other ideas also exciting to me. 

 [Deere](https://www.deere.com/en/index.html) (DE) is big in ARKQ so I bet they prob do that type of stuff but haven't checked. 

[Teradyne](https://www.teradyne.com/) (TER) also does robotics stuff, I used to own it but don't anymore, parents still have it though, I view it as the Yin to the Yang of BL (white collar and blue collar automation plays) maybe their stuff would be applicable?

author: Lukaaaaaaaaaaas
body: There‘s no best ETF. iShares, Lyxor, Vanguard, etc. almost do the same thing and the difference in their success is minimal. Since ETFs are a long term investment, you should pay more attention on TER, physical replication and the costs for an accumulation scheme which depend on your broker.

author: StayClassynet
body: Have you really looked into the cannabis space? If US/MSO exposure is what you're looking for, and really, for weed stocks, that's where the money is, there's really a handful of tickers you should be looking at. In no particular order: TRUL, GTII, CL, CURA. The next rung down includes TER, PLTH, GRWG... but honestly, even then I'd look at one of the major Canadian LPs: APHA/TLRY, CGC, and a distant third would be CRON. Forget all those other Canadian tickers you listed. There's way more risk than upside there. And the weed ETFs carry some of the names I listed above with a bunch of other junk. Save yourself the MER fees.

author: Bashful2
body:
Cgc owns a lot of riv shares (including multiple voting shares which essentially puts riv under their control). 
RIV owns a bunch of ter shares (but not really. RIV's investment in ter will turn into shares once the US federally legalize). Riv also owns two other smaller investments, vert mirabel and tweed tree lot. Tweed tree lot shut down but cgc would still owe riv a few million a year for a long time.
RIV will give cgc these 3 assets in return for $115m cash, 3,750,000 cgc shares, and cgc will cancel all of the shares they own of riv. 
As a riv shareholder, I like it because it 
1. gives us a huge cash position. 
2. We can't do anything with ter shares in the short term anyway. Until fed legalizes 
3. Huge cgc position (which would include ter exposure)
5. ~30% direct return to shareholders due to the cancellation of cgc-owned riv shares 

In my opinion (and general feeling among other riv shareholders) this is a great deal for both sides

author: prefixspan
body: Yep, it's called a [Variable Interest Entity (VIE)](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/v/variable-interest-entity.asp). When you invest in $BABA or $TCEHY or many other Chinese stocks listed in the US, you're actually technically investing in a company in the Cayman Islands that has a contractual right to the original company's profits, but not actual ownership.

author: Dal-Rog
body:
I worked at Shopify for 3 years, and spent a lot of time working closely with their risk department. Trust me, they spend an absolutely crazy amount of money and effort to track down and shutdown fraudulent stores. They use both automation and manual reviews of accounts, and have some very impressive detection technology in place. They also restrict all sorts of high risk type stores from their gateway outright.

They operate their own payment gateway, and both Visa and Mastercard hold heavy obligations to gateway owners when it comes to preventing fraud. Shopify has one of the more sophisticated programs Ive ever seen in my career in SAAS.

The main issue with that type of fraud prevention, is that its always inevitable that fraudsters will start recognizing the approach Shopify uses to detect them, and then they change their patterns. This results generally in a wave of fraudulent stores getting through until reported. Its really an endless game of cat and mouse, and theres some very big companies around the world that constantly open stores and attempt to get around the preventative measures. 

To say that scams don't violate their T&C and that Shopify doesnt care is just downright ridiculous. In the end of the day Shopify ends up eating the costs of the chargebacks when visa and mastercard come calling. Its not only 100% in their best interest to combat fraudulent stores, but they are fully obligated to by owning a payment gateway.

author: hotcakesnsyzzurp
body:

I'm impatient, but then I find something I believe in, I make really concentrated bets, and that's why I was successful with Chewy. I put all my time and money into Chewy, and when I find something that gets me excited I like to swing for the fences but **I wouldn't recommend that for the average investor, and in terms of having the temperaments to deal with the volatility I guess that's kind of the adrenaline that come with being an entrepreneur**"

author: lasagnaphil
body:
This doesn't capture the full story though. Note that after the end of the Bretton Woods system (the policy of pegging US dollars into gold), the US dollar was able to maintain its status as a world reserve currency by using petrodollar recycling (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petrodollar_recycling). In simple terms, observing that oil is what drives the whole production of goods, you go to Middle East companies with a shit ton of oil and make a deal: "I'll protect your land with our strong military, in exchange you sell all your oil in only our US dollars." Since everyone needs oil to make stuff (not just for fuel, it has a ridiculously large amount of utility), every country in the planet now needs to have dollars to fuel their economy, so demand for US dollars skyrockets worldwide.

The problem is, in order to keep the status quo of the dollar from being a global currency, you need to have a constant outflux of dollars from the country, so that is why the US has become an import-driven country with immensely large trade deficits. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triffin_dilemma) As a result, deindustrialization sweeps the country while cheap imports from the overseas replace domestic products, and the country has effectively become one fucking giant shopping mall, all thanks to the troops on Saudi Arabia. Industrial areas heavy affected by deindustrialization (such as the Rust Belt) are fucked over decades, and as a result right-wing populism (ex. Trump) rises as a reactionary force against globalism.

Another problem: who benefits from the US dollar being a global currency? Mainly the bankers (who get to keep churning out dollar-related financial products), and global megacorporations (who get to conduct businesses with credit from the banks). Also, and as bankers start to be the dominant force in politics, credit becomes a solution for everything, so the government let people "borrow" their way out of stagnant low wages and high costs of living (such as housing, medical care, and education) instead of fixing the fundamental problems. This all leads to accelerating economic inequality (especially for the millenials). And while the government bails out large banks and corporations for making risky or even fraudulent decisions (using the well known PRINTER GO BRRR), now there is an increasing left-wing populist voice (ex. Bernie) to fuck those bankers and corporations, and use that newly printed money to the actual people instead. 

While in the states the status-quo Democrats and Republicans (the neolibrerals) are increasingly pressured by populism from both sides (left/right wing), from the foreign world it's going to be a game of musical chairs - it's going to be about who dumps the dollar first. And probably China is going to fire the trigger at some point, as they have stopped buying US treasuries for their surplus dollars from their exports starting from 2013, and instead is loaning those dollars off to other third-world countries for them to build infrastructure, and in return expand their political influence around the world. Also, rethink why China is trying to invest a shit ton of money into renewable energy, they're not just doing this for the "environment", they're also doing it to detach themselves from the petrodollar system. A self-sustainable energy grid without dependence on resources from foreign countries ensures that you'll be more independent from fluctuating oil prices, as well as the political/economical instabilities surrounding it (for example, the Iranian revolution leading to the 1979 oil crisis). 

In conclusion, the US is fucked, and unless you change this current system, coronavirus isn't going to be easily eradicated, and mass evictions and riots will continue to happen. It's either a slow, painful death (maintain the system until it disintegrates) or a quick one (actually try to overhaul the system from what you have).

The words got a little bit dense because it's rather insufficient to capture the problems of the neoliberal US economical/political system in a single Reddit comment. For a much detailed explanation, I recommend reading the article "The Fraying of the Petrodollar System" (https://www.lynalden.com/fraying-petrodollar-system/), as well as Mark Blyth's talk (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KGuaoARJYU0) if you don't like reading too much.

author: tigermaple
body:
Dude, I'LL probably be the one to get downvoted by all the doomsday bears on this sub that have predicted 2000 of the last 2 recessions, but at least get the opposite point of view first. Watch a couple of these talks by Cathie and then tell me you don't think her funds are poised to continue to outperform the SP500 by a considerable margin for the foreseeable future. She is a visionary, correctly predicted Tesla going to $4,000 (pre-split price) and was mocked for it, and I think the more time that goes on the more we will see similar theories of hers that sound far fetched now be proven out.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-IwXJE2ijPA](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-IwXJE2ijPA)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eE6u67Ph768](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eE6u67Ph768)

Plus you're young, now is the time to take more risk and hopefully get more reward! If it doesn't go as planned, you have the advantage of time on your side to recover (either from job earnings or simply waiting for things to go back up). Don't be timid when you're in the time of life to be bold!

author: jesse2h
body:
I used to be a licensed broker on the active trader team @ Schwab.

Fully marginable shares at Schwab have a 30% maintenance requirement. Think basic stuff like Apple, Walmart, Visa. Stocks you won't see swing too wildly in price. Other stocks with more volatility, such as Tesla, have a 65% maintenance requirement.

Maintenance requirement means the amount of your investment you need to *personally own.* I can sit on $100,000 in Apple stock (and realize the gains of 100k of apple) that I only had $30,000 to pay for. Schwab would front me the other $70,000, if I had appropriate collateral in my account. Keep in mind if it drops by a penny, I'm now in a maintenance call.

Anyway, because of GME's recently crazy volatility, they bumped the maintenance requirement to 200%. If I have $10k in GME, not only do I need to own those shares outright, it's going to eat into another $10k off of the rest of my marginable securities, forcing me to have more equity in my account. Schwab also put a 200% maint req on Kodak when that crazy bullshit was going on.

author: turtels_wb
body:
Just to add a few thing people seem to miss:

* Canoo has been moving fast since 2018, working with industry leaders (MT before steel was considered cool. Just read MT take on Canoo  [Canoo unveils game changing subscription-based steel-intensive electric vehicle (arcelormittal.com)](https://automotive.arcelormittal.com/news_and_stories/cases/2019CanooBEV) .
* Roush manufacturing built Canoo's beta vehicles ( [CANOO + ROUSH - YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JvWFpnUbRv8&feature=emb_logo&ab_channel=Canoo) ).
* Canoo vehicles were designed and built from the ground-up, not some ICE retrofitted with duracell bunnies.
* Executive Chairman Tony Aquila has been in automotive software industry since 2005 with Solera (risk assessment and insurance);
*  Tony is also the Founder, Chairman & CEO of AFV Partners, which is a global holding company invested in:

1. Aviation technology software ( [Aircraft Performance Group: APG (flyapg.com)](https://flyapg.com/) ,  [RocketRoute | Flight Plan | Marketplace | Concierge](https://www.rocketroute.com/) , [Seattle Avionics](https://www.seattleavionics.com/) ).
2. Canoo.

Connect the dots:

Autonomous robo-taxis are the future, but you need data and software, that's what aviation software vertical can provide, however, it is still too early for autonomous, but Canoo provides a flexible platform which can be easily upgraded later.

author: TitaniumShovel
body:
Check out https://www.optionsprofitcalculator.com/

If you really want to learn and you use Robinhood, this video is as good as it gets:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SD7sw0bf1ms

You should really be thinking of options as just that, options. You are paying a **premium** to buy a **contract** which gives you the option to **buy 100 shares** at the desired **strike price** anytime from now until the **expiration date**. You can **exercise** this option at anytime, or you can sell the contract back for a profit/loss.

But yes, it's essentially a "bet." I think that video explains all you need to know. Watch it in chunks so you don't overwhelm yourself.

author: Apathetic_Answer_
body:
The classic advice is hold a bond fund and rebalance periodically. Companies like MCD, JNJ, and V outperform bear markets as well as distribute (trigger warning) dividends, which can provide much needed cash flows in a down market. Also just parking cash in money market accounts can protect against interest rate risk.

In reality a good portfolio that protects against bear markets will include several strategies.

Or YOLO SPY puts.

author: apfejes
body:
I just started my own company - the second time I've done this in Canada.  I wanted to say "This isn't true!" when I read the article, but the further I read, the more I agreed with it.  

My first company has succeeded and is a Canadian success story - a public biotech, though I was pushed out after 3 years, so I wasn't part of it from start to end.  I was there as CSO long enough to do SR&ED, though.  It was soul-sucking.  I've heard others use that term and I whole heartedly agree.  Soul-sucking is exactly the right word for it.  However, the company was a biotech, so it was possible to build those milestones and write all those summaries in a way that didn't rip out all of the innovation from the company.  The whole thing fell to me to write it up, so the engineers were isolated from it while I was there.

This time around, I'm CEO, and we've taken a different strategy.  We will look for Canadian funds, eventually, but our first investors are international, and we're trying to draw Bay Area money north.  We're going to pretend we're in the Bay Area, really, and just do things the Bay Area way.  I spent the last 6 years there at startups, and I've got a good sense of what that culture entails.  There are ways to bring that culture North.

I have to say, though, that this trap is worse than even the article suggests.  My co-founder isn't canadian, but we want to bring him to Canada to continue working here.  The time zone difference to Europe is kinda rough, and we can't do it forever.  However, in order to bring him here on a startup founders visa, we need to have a Canadian investor - exactly what the article warns is one of the problems.  It's not sufficient to have investors, it has to be an investor from the list of "acceptable Canadian investors."  That is utter bullshit, but hey, we're still too small to argue that with the government.

As the article points out - Canada thinks it's helping startups, but in reality, it's stifling them.

author: truemeliorist
body:
Just piggybacking this - make sure you know what sort of things you want to overweight in the tech sector, and then compare that to the holdings against VGT.

Tech covers a lot of areas. What does "tech" mean to you? 

VGT is companies like Microsoft, Oracle, Apple, Visa, etc. All rock solid companies. But, they're almost all well established with large market caps.

If you are looking for disruptive small tech companies that haven't hit the hockey stick yet, VGT isn't what you are looking for. And you'd be dismayed to see a lot of those are also excluded from vanguard small cap funds like VB as well.

It helps to know what you are looking for and why.

author: Botboy141
body:
Glancing back through some of his "investment thesis" videos in the past. Back on July 13, 2020, $GME made up 1.18% of his portfolio ([https://youtu.be/7wjWnMcdnlQ?t=2963](https://youtu.be/7wjWnMcdnlQ?t=2963)).

His entire investment thesis is about finding underperforming companies that are failing or at least trailing their peers, to see if they can come back (usually a reasonably deep dive into cash flows), management, industry, etc (including technical voodoo). He is the opposite of the meme stock investor, that's probably my favorite part.

Investment Style: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1zi7XVudxME&list=PLlsPosngRnZ1ZYcer6iZBVKMt1f8HeW0j](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1zi7XVudxME&list=PLlsPosngRnZ1ZYcer6iZBVKMt1f8HeW0j)

author: Wassimply
body:
Micheal Klein has very close tights to the Saudis and has met the crown prince MBS. 

Sam Altman the founder of YC is on if the operating partner of [$CCIV](https://stocktwits.com/symbol/CCIV)  he met with the crown prince of Saudi Arabia in his silicon valley visit. 

Micheal Klein was speaking at the The Future Investment Initiative in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia  hosted by the Public Investment Fund of Saudi Arabia who are the main backers of Lucid Motors.  [youtube.com/watch?v=IYKOPPC...](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IYKOPPCrwXM&t=13s)  

The saudis love him and they won't such a deal with anyone else or miss on the IPO EV boom.    

This confirms the rumour for me.

author: bigkev2569
body: I got banned two days ago for saying ÇČî V was getting options.  I hope whoever saw my comment bought some and makes tendies tomorrow.

Oh boy, again with Michael Burry.

We've been over this about how he's wrong on the ETF bubble.

In terms of ETF redemption with market makers they have hundreds of thousands of shares to play with.

There is no ETF bubble. Index funds still make up a small minority of trades on markets today. Most trades are still done by active funds and active management, so valuations and price discovery aren't out of whack.

Most ETFs trade on the secondary market - ie. Between me and you, not the market makers or authorized participants.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wv0pJh8mFk0

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1s7ULX45fjw

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ocJH1HRR09g

AUM doesn't set pricing - trading does.

And who trades the most? Hedge funds and active portfolio managers.

He also assumes some of the most qualified and professional index constructors - MSCI, Blackrock, and Vanguard, are wrong about how they construct their indexes. And yet we also have active managers that are really just closet indexers.

author: _dragonlungs_
body: I'm going to assume you are genuinely curious and respond that yes immigrants rent in downtown Toronto, all the time. Quite a few people I've met while working in the city are young people applying for PRs. Some are international students who studied here, and then chose to stay and build a life here. Others arrived by visa to work temporarily, but decided Canada was pretty great and also applied for residency.

author: IDGAFSIGH
body:
They also said it was DEFINITELY not a V-shaped recovery but rather a K or L shaped recovery when the market crashed last year. It turned out to be the fastest and most profitable V-shaped recovery in the history of the stock market. We're talking about the  best of the best hedge fund managers, US treasury leaders, king of bonds making these calls and they were all wrong.

Nobody knows when the market will crash just like nobody knows whether we're on another 10-year bull run right now.
